titleStmt.title: Walters Ms. W.37, Book of Hours (Use of Liège)
Calendar
Prefatory image cycle
Hours of the Nativity of the Virgin
Seven Penitential Psalms
Fifteen Gradual Psalms
Litany
Long Hours of the Holy Spirit
Office of the Dead
Book of Hours

availability.p: Licensed for use under Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported Access Rights, http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/legalcode. It is requested that copies of any published articles based on the information in this data set be sent to the curator of manuscripts, The Walters Art Museum, 600 North Charles Street, Baltimore MD 21201.

notesStmt.note: This small but richly illuminated Book of Hours was made ca. 1300-10 for the Use of Liège. The manuscript was created for a woman, likely a Beguine living in Huy, and inscriptions indicate it continued to be used in that region by another family into the seventeenth century. The number and variety of illuminations in the manuscript are remarkable given its small size, for it contains fourteen extant full-page miniatures, twenty-four calendar images, eleven extant large historiated initials, 188 small historiated initials, and countless marginal drolleries. Although an early rebinding resulted in the loss or rearrangement of several folios, this manuscript remains a fine example of the richness and intimacy of a Book of Hours from this period.

msContents.textLang: The primary language in this manuscript is Latin. The secondary language of this manuscript is French, Old (842-ca.1400).

msItem.title: Calendar
msItem.note: Use of Liège; one quarter to one half full; graded in red and black ink; twenty-eight virgin saints shows considerable female representation; many saints of Huy indicate intended usage there; notable saints include Mengold (February 8, count of Huy), Lambert (April 28), Domitian (May 7, bishop of Tongres and Huy, patron of Huy), Gengulf (May 11), Servatius (May 13, bishop of Tongres), Monegund (July 1), Helen (August 18, "regine," and the only other with this saint listed this way is British Library Harley 2930, which is also from Liège and made for a woman who was likely a Beguine), Lambert (September 17, bishop of Liège, patron saint of diocese), Remigius (October 1), Hubert (November 3, bishop of Liège, buried at St.-Pierre, Liège), Leonard (November 6), Geneviève (November 26, "Genofeue," also uniquely found this way in a group of Liège manuscripts, see Oliver, 1988), Begga (December 17, "uidue," patron saint of Beguines

msItem.title: Hours of the Nativity of the Virgin
msItem.note: Use of Liège; text begins imperfectly with the first of nine lessons in Matins

msItem.title: Seven Penitential Psalms
msItem.incipit: Domine ne in furore tuo arguas me

msItem.title: Fifteen Gradual Psalms
msItem.rubric: Ici commencent les .xv. p psalmes con doit dire por les pechies.
msItem.note: Psalms 119-133; text gap after fol. 120 due to missing leaf: fol. 120v ends "lingua nostra exul" (Ps. 125.2), and fol. 121r resumes "Cum dederit dilectis suis" (Ps. 126.2)

msItem.title: Litany
msItem.note: Page missing after fol. 128; fols. 127r-129r: litany; fols. 129r-130v: petitions and invocations; fols. 130v-132r: invocations; fols. 132r-134r: four collects; list of confessors and virgins now incomplete with loss of folio after fol. 128; sixteen apostles, from John the Baptist to Luke; thirteen martyrs, which include Lambert, Adalbert, Mengold (connected to Huy), Urban, Dionysius, Donatus, and Romanus; the first confessors listed are Silvester, Leo and Gregory; the last virgins listed are Lucy, Gertrude, Walburga, Euphrasia, Anne, Elizabeth, Mary Magdalene, Mary of Egypt

msItem.title: Long Hours of the Holy Spirit
msItem.rubric: Ici commencent les hores del saint espir.

msItem.title: Office of the Dead
msItem.note: Text is incomplete and scrambled due to misbinding following fol. 178; correct order is as follows: fols. 185-187 (missing 1 folio), 190 (missing 1 folio), 188, 189 (missing 1 folio), 191-194, 196, 179-184, 195, and 197
Use of Liège; collect beginning on fol. 195r is for female suppliant

support.p: Medium weight, well prepared parchment; thicker pages used for prefatory miniatures

supportDesc.foliation: Flyleaves are modern parchment, contemporary with later binding; first two folios were originally blank but structurally part of the first quire

p.formula: Front flyleaves: i ; Quire 1: 6 (fols. 1-6); Quire 2: 2 (fols. 7-8); Quire 3: 4 (fols. 9-12); Quire 4: remnant of quire of undetermined size, now containing 3 folios (fols. 13-15); Quires 5-8: 10 (fols. 16-55); Quire 9: 10, lacking the eighth folio (fols. 56-64); Quires 10-11: 10 (fols. 65-84); Quires 12-13: 8 (fols. 85-100); Quire 14-15: 10 (fols. 101-120); Quire 16: 10, lacking the first and eighth folios (fols. 121-128); Quires 17-21: 10 (fols. 129-178); Quire 22: 8, lacking first and eighth folios (fols. 179-184); Quire 23: 8, with the fifth folio tipped in (fols. 185-193); Quire 24: 4 (fols. 194-197); Back flyleaves: i
p.signatures: Visible on lower right corners, rectos, fols. 139r-143r, "o" to "o////"
p.catchwords: Lower right corners, versos, beginning on fol. 25v, except on folios with miniatures

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled in brown ink; layout does not apply to the calendar

handDesc.handNote: Calendar: textura; main text: rounded textura, with major medial pauses marked by punctus elevatus, and final pauses by punctus; ownership entries on fols. 1v-2r written in cursive in gray-brown ink

decoDesc.decoNote: "KL" in blue, rose, and gold begins each calendar page; labor of the month and zodiac symbols in lozenges for each month

Full-page miniature and facing large historiated initial lacking after fol. 12, and full-page miniature lacking after fol. 62; full-page miniatures fols. 32v, 48v, 69v, 76v, 83v, and 92v; large historiated initials fols. 33r, 49r, 63r, 70r, 77r, 84r, and 93r; small historiated initials fols. 13r, 14r, 15r-v, 18r, 19r, 20r, 21r, 22r, 23r, 24v, 26r, 27v, 28v, 29v, 30v, 33v, 35r, 36r, 37r, 39r, 40v, 41v, 42r-v, 43r, 44v, 45v, 46r-v, 47r-v, 48r, 49r-v, 50v, 51r, 52r, 53r-v, 58r, 60v, 62r, 63r-v, 64v, 65r, 66r, 67r-v, 68v, 69r, 79r-v, 71v, 72r, 73r, 74v, 75v, 76r, 77r-v, 78v, 79r, 80r-v, 81v, 82v, 83r, 84r, 85r, 86r, 87r, 88r, 89r, 90r-v, 91v, 92r, 93r-v, 94v, 95r, 97r-v, 98r, and 99r-v
Full-page miniature fol. 100v; large historiated initial fol. 101r; small historiated initials fols. 102v, 104r, 107r, 109r, 112r, 113r, and 115r

Small historiated initial lacking for the opening of Ps. 126 after fol. 120; full-page miniature fol. 115v; large historiated initial fol. 116r; small historiated initials fols. 116r, 117r, 118v, 119r, 120r-v, 121r, 122r-v, 123v, 124r, and 126r-v
Full-page miniature fol. 134v; large historiated initial fol. 135r; small historiated initials fols. 135v, 136v, 137v, 138v, 139r-v, 141v, 142r-v, 143r-v, 144v, 145r-v, 146r-v, and 147r-v

Full-page miniature fol. 148v; large historiated initial fol. 149r; small historiated initials fols. 150r, 151r-v, 152v, 153v, 154v, 156v, 157v, 160r, 161r, 164r, 165r, 167v, 169v, 170v, 171v, 173r, 176r, 178v, 179v, 181r, 182r, 182v, 184r, 186v, 188r, 190r, 191v, 193r, 194r, and 195r-v

Two full-page miniatures and one large historiated initial missing; fourteen extant full-page miniatures; twenty-four calendar illuminations with labors and zodiac symbols for each month (13 lines); eleven extant large historiated initials (8 to 10 lines) face full-page miniatures; 188 small historiated initials (4 lines) at secondary text divisions; drolleries throughout; alternating gold and blue versals with blue and red pen flourishes throughout (1 line); borders formed of prolonged extenders of initials; line fillers in litany have geometric or floral designs, birds, or beasts; rubrics in red; text in black ink

binding.p: Bound in Belgium, ca. fifteenth or sixteenth century; brown leather over wood boards; rebacked, corners repaired, and resewn on five single cords by Gruel in Paris in late nineteenth or early twentieth century; upper and lower covers have panel stamped design in blind with two columns of four motifs, each in a square, with fleur-de-lis flanking a paschal lamb and an eagle; inscription down center of imagery reads "AVE MARIA GRACIA;" spine rounded and backed; worn gilt edges; evidence of two metal fore-edge clasps on upper and lower boards

history.provenance: Created for use in Liège ca. 1300-1310, likely for a female owner, possibly a Beguine living in Huy (diocese of Liège) based on saints in the calendar (see that section for details); reference to a female suppliant in a collect on fol. 195r

Owned by Fizinne family of Huy (also spelled Fisinne, Fisen, and Fisenne) from at least 1410 until after 1604; inscription on fols. 1v-2r reads: "Guillaulme de Fizinne prieur de Buylon [Bouillon]" (d. 1410); Guillaulme seigneur de Fizinne" (d. 1474); his daughter "Jehanne de Fizinne" (d. 1558), who apparently had the book rebound; her daughter "Margarite de Daulin" (d. 1559), cited as "ma mere" by scribe of ownership entries; her son "Sire Jehan Connart (?)," canon of Huy (d. 1577); his gift to "Jean Sire de Fizinne" (d. 1604), who gave it to his daughter "Catherine...damme de hauresay [?]" (d. 1596); her daughter "Anne de Woha [?];" "et depuys au hault Vowe [?] de Sironville"

Léon Gruel and Robert Engelmann collection, Paris, late nineteenth or early twentieth century; their bookplate "GE" inscribed "No. 390," and descriptive dealer slip formerly affixed to front flyleaf (now in file)
Henry Walters, Baltimore, purchased from Gruel between 1905 and 1931
history.acquisition: Walters Art Museum, 1931, by Henry Walters' bequest
